lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six times (one o'clock, one ten, one fifteen, one thirty, one forty-five, two o'clock) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use clock flashcards or draw clock faces. Say: “One fifteen.” Students point to the matching time or draw hands on a blank clock.
stretchStrategies: Students work in pairs to create a “school day schedule” poster showing six different clock times and corresponding school activities. They must present it to the class using full sentences (e.g., “At one fifteen, we have art class.”)

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about time using “What time is it?” and respond with “It’s...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Model: “What time is it?” – “It’s one thirty.” Use a mini clock or flashcards. Students practise Q&A in pairs using clock visuals.
stretchStrategies: Students work in pairs to create a “school day schedule” poster showing six different clock times and corresponding school activities. They must present it to the class using full sentences (e.g., “At one fifteen, we have art class.”)

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What time is it?” / “It’s ___.” to talk about time.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write 3 model Q&As on the board. Erase parts and have students complete aloud: “What time is it?” – “It’s ___.”
stretchStrategies: Students work in pairs to create a “school day schedule” poster showing six different clock times and corresponding school activities. They must present it to the class using full sentences (e.g., “At one fifteen, we have art class.”)

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
